About Me.name: Daniel Chen
About Me.summary: Experienced Cloud Support Engineer with over six years in diverse technical roles, specializing in application development, customer support, and user experience improvement within agile environments

Experience.name: IBM in Durham, NC
Experience.summary: At IBM, I boosted cloud service efficiency, becoming a top case closer in North America while delivering exceptional customer satisfaction. My problem-solving and leadership drove projects beyond their goals, demonstrating my dedication to success.

Experience.name: LINKMedicine in Balimore, MD
Experience.summary: At LINKMedicine, I developed WeChat mini program prototypes and webpages, improving user experience and aligning with branding, thereby enhancing digital engagement.

projects.name: Team Wiki, Project Lead
projects.summary: I led the development of a knowledge base to enhance team self-sufficiency, compiling key information such as service issues, troubleshooting, and best practices into easily accessible service pages. I also promoted team involvement and added a feedback form to the site, fostering a culture of continuous improvement and collaboration that significantly optimized our collective knowledge.

projects.name: Service Level Objective Analysis, Project Lead
projects.summary: I conducted a comprehensive analysis on tickets missing our first response goals, pinpointing root causes and developing strategies to address them. Through leading weekly team meetings focused on implementing these solutions, we boosted our workflow efficiency, increasing our average attainment rate from 80% to over 95% within a year, demonstrating significant performance improvement through strategic teamwork.

awards.title: SAPA Hopkins
awards.summary: Received first place in biohealth innovation for the conceptualization of our application, which was designed to help users make rational decisions about healthcare by employing complex analyses of big medical data. Our concept beat more than 15 other teams, winning 34.7% of the total votes in an annual forum with more than 1000 participants, including multinational pharmaceutical companies, investment firms, and research institutions.'
